Title: the einstein approximation

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon is stood in the middle of the room. His whiteboard is behind him. Every few moments he turns round suddently.
Leonard’s bedroom. Sheldon is standing over their bed. He knocks on the wall.
(Sheldon once again keeps popping up his head and shouting “Bazinga” as Leonard flails around trying to catch him.)
Penny: Interesting. I usually just have coffee. You’ve been up all night?
Oh, sorry, sweetie, I can’t help you till I’ve had my coffee.
For me, the worst part was when people saw us leave with them.
Oh, what a gentleman. Hey, Sheldon. (Steps on marbles which are all over the floor, screams and falls)
Oh, you’ve been falling all night. You’re used to it.
Toad of truth? Is that a physics thing?
Leonard, you’re… you’re giggling in your sleep.
Hey, you know what, Leonard, I know I said I could handle your roommate, but I was wrong. We’re going to have to break up.
Okay, I’ll get those drinks started for you.
Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
No, wait, wait, no, wait. Wh.. what are you doing here?
You just, you just walked in and they hired you, just like that?
Sheldon, wait, this isn’t even what I do. I’m a waitress, not a busboy.
Hey, guys, sorry you had to wait, but we are swamped. What’s this?
Sheldon, where are you going? Aren’t you going to clean this up?
Sheldon: I’m attempting to view my work as a fleeting peripheral image so as to engage the superior colliculus of my brain.
Is it morning?
Then I’ve been up all night.
Why else would a person try to engage their superior colliculus?
Captain Hook’s hand was eaten by a crocodile, not an alligator. If you’re going to mock me, at least get your facts straight.
I can’t see it! It just won’t coalesce.
You’re right. (Takes whiteboard to window and throws it out. Picks up a new one) It’s a great idea, Leonard. Thank you.
Electrons move through graphene, act as if they have no mass…
Unit cell contains two carbon atoms. Interior angle of a hexagon is 120 degrees.
Structure, constant structure. One atom…
Pattern is the same as fermions, travels on the pathways, hexagonal, it’s always hexagonal…
Not lima beans, carbon atoms.
Peas! Perfect, they can be electrons.
Don’t be ridiculous. What would I do with corn?
The plural of coccyx is coccyges.
Good Lord! You’re ruining everything!
The same thing I’ve been doing for three days. Trying to figure out why electrons behave as if they have no mass when travelling through a graphene sheet.
Well, I needed something bigger than peas, now, didn’t I?
I don’t know, two, three days. Not important. I don’t need sleep, I need answers. I need to determine where in this swamp of unbalanced formulas squatteth the toad of truth.
They lose their sensitivity to serotonin and norepinephrine.
Impaired cognitive function.
But I don’t want to go to bed.
Oh, all right.
Size ratio was all wrong. Couldn’t visualize it. Needed bigger carbon atoms.
Back door has a five-pin tumbler system, single-circuit alarm. Child’s play. You can start sorting protons and neutrons while I build carbon atoms.
But I’m still working.
You can try, but you’ll never catch me. (He disappears under the balls)
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.
I have good news.
Your cell phone was off.
And that didn’t work out, did it?
I came to tell you I’ve got the answer.
No, no, I’m still hopelessly stuck on that, but I figured out how to figure it out.
Einstein.
Albert Einstein.
When Albert Einstein came up with special relativity, he was working at the patent office.

Don’t be absurd. That’s in Washington. You know I could never live in a city whose streets are laid out in a wheel-and-spoke pattern. No. I’m going to find a similarly menial job where my basal ganglia are occupied with a routine task, freeing my prefrontal cortex to work quietly in the background on my problem.
Of course it is. Even talking to you is sufficiently menial that I can feel the proverbial juices starting to flow.
You’re welcome. Good night to you, too. Oh, by the way, I was watching you sleep for a moment, and I noticed that your snoring seems to be worse when you’re on your back.
No, I wasn’t talking to Leonard.
A menial job. Like yours.

I do. For thousands of years, the lowest classes of the human race have spent their lives labouring to erect monuments under the lash of their betters, until finally they dropped down and became one with the dust through which they trudged. Do you have anything like that?
Shouldn’t you check your database?
You didn’t really type.
Oh, that would be good! Sawing, hammering, eating out of a lunch pail as my working-class fellows and I sit perched precariously on a girder high above the metropolis.
I could do that.
One question.
What’s sheetrock?
That seems acceptable.
I don’t drive.
Senior theoretical particle physicist at CalTech, focusing on M theory, or, in layman’s terms, string theory.
I’m trying to get these tables cleared. We’re slammed.

A reasonable question. I asked myself, what is the most mind-numbing, pedestrian job conceivable, and three answers came to mind, uh, toll booth attendant, an Apple Store genius, and what Penny does. Now, since I don’t like touching other people’s coins, and I refuse to contribute to the devaluation of the word genius, here I am.
Oh, heavens, no. Since I don’t need to be paid, I didn’t need to be hired. I simply came in, picked up a tray, and started working for the man. Let me get that plate out of your way.
Is it? Just a moment ago I had a minor epiphany regarding the polymer degradation phenomenon while scraping congealed nachos off a plate. Bernadette, table 10 wants their check.
You’re right. That is more menial. Hello, I’m Sheldon. I’ll be your server today. I don’t recommend the salmon. I saw it in the kitchen.

All right, one bacon cheeseburger, breaking two Jewish dietary restrictions simultaneously, kudos. Beer-battered fish and chips. Now, here’s your tartar sauce. I also brought you salsa. It’s a little unconventional, but I think you’ll like it. It’s zingy. And for you, Factory Burrito Grande, no cheese, no sour cream, no ugly consequences from your lactose intolerance. Bon appétit.
Yes.
Of course.
Nope.
Yep.
I do.
I’m sorry. I don’t work here.
Leonard: Penny, I told you if you don’t put him in his crate at night he just runs around the apartment.
Mmm, he’s either isolating the terms of his formula and examining them individually, or looking for the alligator that swallowed his hand after Peter Pan cut it off.
Aye, aye, Captain.
Maybe you need a fresh start.
Intellectually about 30 hours. Emotionally about 29 years.
No, I think it’s a firmware problem.
I think Penny likes to skate. The four of us could double.
Yeah, this morning he used a stick of butter as deodorant.
I haven’t seen him this stuck since he tried to figure out the third Matrix movie.
Here, you want my peas?
So roller skating, should we all grab a bite to eat first?
Great. Your mom’s not coming, right?
You had some nice moves out there, Howard.
Yeah. Did you notice all the people looking at us?
Sorry. I’m moving a little slow. I think I bruised my coccyx.
Don’t tell Koothrappali. After you.
Oh, my God! Are you… (falls as well)
Are you okay?
Don’t bark at me. I fell, too.
No, that’s a crazy thing.
That was amazing how you handled him.
It’s not me, it’s my new ringtone. The Joker from Batman.
Me, too, but I paid three bucks for it.
Hello. Yeah, I’m Leonard Hofstadter. Yeah, yeah, he’s my roommate. Oh, God, is he okay? Yeah, alright, alright, I’ll be right there.
Sheldon’s escaped and is terrorizing the village.
Hi. I’m Dr. Hofstadter. Where is he?
Thanks for not calling the cops.
Yeah, well, he’s extra special. Hey, Shelly. What you doing?
Sure, sure. How did you get into this place?
No, I don’t think so. We need to go home now.
If you don’t come out of there, I’m going to have to drag you out.
For God’s sakes. Sheldon, come here!
What?
And you had to barge in here and wake us up in the middle of the night?
Because we didn’t want to be disturbed.
Really? You figured out the graphene problem?
What are you talking about?
Yeah, I’m going to need a little more.
Keep going.
So, you’re going to go work at the patent office?
Sounds like a great plan.
Okay, well, thanks for sharing with us. Good night.
Told you.
Hang on. Black beans, not pinto beans?
Double guacamole?
No cilantro?
Lettuce shredded, not chopped?
You understand why I’m doing this to you?
That’ll be all. That was fun.
I heard about this professor at MIT who melted down, bought a van, and spent the rest of his life as a mobile dog groomer.
Only to shampoo Professor Chambourg’s shih tzu.
Yeah, that’s the only thing wrong with that plan.
Sheldon took our order.
Well, honey, not to complain, but we were starting to think you didn’t either.
Sheldon, come here.
Howard: How long has he been stuck?
Oh, that’s perfect. Bernadette’s been hocking me to take her roller skating.
What could be better? We’re in.
Boy, he’s really gone, isn’t he?
Good. P.F. Chang’s? My mom has coupons.
Not really. I was in my boogie zone.
Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
I bet if we all chipped in, we could buy Sheldon a van.
Raj (arriving): Hey, it’s Disco Night at the Moonlight Roller Rink in Glendale tonight. Who’s up for getting down?
Raj: Great. It’s not like I brought it up because I wanted to go.
No, it’s okay. I don’t have to go. I’m happy just to guide you and your ladies to suitable entertainment choices. I’m a walking brown Yelp.com.
But if I don’t eat my lima beans, I can’t have my cookie.
Okay, just to be clear, roller skating was my idea, and I’m very unhappy that you turned it into a double date, and I hope you both fall on your asses and break your coccyxes.
Screw you. Give me back my lima beans.
How long can he keep this up?
He never went back to the university?
I’m on a cloud. Swing me. (Howard swings Raj several times.)
Raj (as Sheldon reaches out and grabs fr: Hey, those are my lima beans!
Bernadette: Oh, my God, have you ever been so embarrassed?
I don’t know which was lamer, their roller-skating or their disco dancing.
When Howard tried to do the splits…
Sheldon, when was the last time you got any sleep?
Okay, Sheldon. What happens to our neuroreceptors when we don’t get enough REM sleep?
Right, so march in there, brush your teeth and go to bed.
I’m going to count to three. One…
I know how to deal with stubborn children. My mother used to run an illegal day care centre in our basement.
Security Guard: Oh, hey, it’s no big deal. My sister’s got a kid who’s special.
Sheldon (popping his head up): Bazinga. (Disappears, pops up in another place) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga.
Employment Office Assistant: So, Mr. Cooper, you’re looking for a job.
Assistant: Why, thank you for noticing. I’m Menial Employee of the Month. Do you have a particular field in mind?
I didn’t really have to. So, how about construction?
No, no. This is putting up sheetrock at a housing project in Rosemead.
Moving on. How about doing deliveries for a florist?
Do you have your own car?
Of course you don’t. Mr. Cooper, let me just ask you a question. What was your last job?
I see. Just give me a second. Security!
Sheldon (drops tray. A nearby table clap: Is that really necessary? Good Lord. The interference pattern in the fracture. The motion of the wave through the molecular structure. I’ve been looking at it all wrong. I can’t consider the electrons as particles. They move through the graphene as a wave. It’s a wave! The moment to applaud would be now. Troglodytes.

I see. Just give me a second. Security!
Okay, I’ll get those drinks started for you.
Sheldon (appearing in an apron and carrying a tray)

I’m trying to get these tables cleared. We’re slammed.
No, wait, wait, no, wait. Wh.. what are you doing here?
